posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi Kyhe!

Could I just ask a couple of questions before anything else, please? When you say "Monk only", does that mean you can't multiclass at all? What are these "Fiery Fist" abilities? How is your PW when it comes to available goodies such as gloves, robes, boots, kamas, etc - and what sort of bonuses do they give (+1? +3? +5?)?

I've a couple of ideas in mind, but which to go for kind of depends on your answers. I just wouldn't want to embark on something unhelpful.

Cheers

posts.author: Kyhe
posts.content:
Hey Stagmeister,

Yes, its mean you arent at all allowed to multiclass whe you take monk as a class. So there is this restriction for classes.

As for the Fiery Fist ability, its an ability to gain basically the "flame Weapon" spell on your gloves/kama/sai etc. for the same number of turns as your wisdom score.

The PW, is very kind when it comes to having different gloves with attirbutes for a monk, though they may/can be hard to come by. Kama and monk weapons not much more then a +1/+3 kinda a things with a little added bonus now and then. its possible to get robes that has dmg reduction on them, or ac against specific dmg type, like blud, slash, piercing.

 :)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks Kyhe, that helps.

One thought, if you're looking at a Dex build, would be to dual-wield kamas. You'd have the required number of feats to get Weapon Focus, Weapon Finesse, Ambidexterity, TWF, ITWF, Blind Fight and Imp Crit. Obviously, you'd have one more feat if you went human (as well as 23 more skill points) for something else - maybe Power Attack to boost damage, or Expertise to help AC (depending on what we go for in Int). That said, going with elf helps with Dex.

What that would mean is that while your damage per hit won't be as great as unarmed, you'll hit more frequently. The Monk attack schedule is not to be sniffed at.

Of course, this would be very much a combat-focused build, so you'd prefer something more defensive, that can be explored.

What do you think?

Cheers

posts.content:
Sounds ok, though im wondering :).

The Reason for Dex, is to gain AC from tumble/parry (parry gives +1 ac pr 5 lvls on this PW) and most importantly higher Hide/MS. Just after a quick talk with some of the players, it seems that gloves are more "enchanced" to come by then Kamas on the server:

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
That's fine - unarmed it is. That gives us 3 more feats to play with. I'll go have a think...

Btw, the way Tumble impacts on AC isn't dependent on Dex. Every five ranks you place in the skill boosts AC by +1, it doesn't matter if you're Dex, Str, Cha, Wis, Int or Con based. And Monk has it as a class skill, so you'll be able to get +4AC from it. So, what have they done with Parry, because that sounds very different from the nerfed skill in vanilla?

Cheers

posts.author: Kyhe
posts.content:
they have done the following :) :
SpoilerParry allows the character to block incoming attacks and make spectacular counterattacks. For every five skill points (including Dexterity and other modifiers, up to maximum 30 points before armor check penalty) the character's armor class is also improved by +1 when fighting in melee without a shield. This bonus is halved when fighting with a heavy weapon unless the character has the Improved Parry feat. When fighting with a shield, for every ten skill points the character's armor class is improved by +1. With the Shield Parry feat, the character's armor class is improved by +1 for every five skill points when fighting with a shield.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Okay, what do you think of this as a first draft?

I was torn between taking Expertise as a feat that gives +5AC, or Parry as a skill that will bring +4AC. Each are selected in combat, so you wouldn't be able to use both at the same time. Here I decided on Expertise, to free up more skill points, but if you'd like to change that you'd then be able to drop Int to 12, with that 1 spare point available for Con or Str - neither of which would help in itself, but any gear that boosts those stats with +1, +3, etc would be more usable.

Anyway, here's a first go...

17

19

Over to you...

Cheers

EDIT: I've just realized that you can get +5AC with Parry, because it takes into account your Dex modifier. So you could lose Spellcraft and take 19 points in Parry (still leaving 7 spare) instead, drop Expertise and maybe Power Attack to get Skill Focuses in both Hide and Move Silently (bringing Blind Fight to level 1 and taking the Skill Foci at 9 and 12).

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Kyhe wrote: Hi Stagmeister, this looks quite interesting. i see there is only 10 con, i take it due to the ac and dodge of a monk this isnt really a problem :)? i would like to add, that Parry doesnt need to be activated to gain the AC boost.

to add to that, Mick (who guessed the PW) is saying about the bonus feats, i believe its up to 5 extra feats, i cant remember where they are in the progression though.
The problem we have with Con is that to even raise it to 10 takes 4 points at character generation for an elf, as it has -2 to its Con, so to take it to 12 would take 6 points, and that means losing 2 from somewhere else. So realistically it's either Str, which would further limit your damage, or Wis, which would drop your AC and Will save by 1. I'm quite alright to drop the Str to 10 for an extra 20 hps and +1 to the Fort save if you'd prefer - it was merely personal preference on my part for a build that's concentrating on not getting hit at all (indeed, I'd thought about Dodge rather than Expertise as well for that extra +1AC vs current opponent). Your call, really.

And if that's the case with Parry, then it's definitely a better option than Expertise here - you'd only lose the +2 saves vs spells. Or you could even take them both, so that when in Expertise mode you could have a naked pre-epic AC of 36, which is insane, frankly.

It would be really, really helpful to find out more about those extra feats, though. They could make a world of difference

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks for the link, Mirnaia, it's a pretty comprehensive analysis. However, as with many comprehensive analyses, it does rather lose itself in the detail at times - sort of like saying, "that's a tree", "that's a tree", "that's a tree", "that's a tree", without recognizing that the whole thing's a forest. The prime example being that separating offence from defence, while all very laudable in statistical terms, misses the balance between the two that Monk achieves (or can achieve in a good build, anyway) better than any other class (imho).

Nevertheless, as you say, it's worth a read!
